author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Birthday for Breonna: A Campaign to Mourn and Honor
description: On Friday, when Breonna Taylor would have turned 27, demonstrators focused attention on her case.
content: — Cate Young, a Los Angeles based film and culture critic who founded #BirthdayForBreonna
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Fight Over Inflammatory Language
description: Facebook employees staged a virtual “walkout” over the company’s hands-off policy toward President Trump’s inflammatory posts.
content: The coronavirus and its economic fallout has been particularly debilitating for black Americans. They have been more likely to fall ill and lose jobs or income since the pandemic began, an ugly disparity that added to the racial strife that boiled over. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the week ahead. Stay safe out there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Top Editor of Philadelphia Inquirer Resigns After ‘Buildings Matter’ Headline
description: Stan Wischnowski, a 20-year veteran of the paper, stepped down days after the publication of an article that led to a walkout by dozens of Inquirer journalists.
content: Stan Wischnowski, the top editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, resigned on Saturday, days after an article with the headline “Buildings Matter, Too,” on the effects of civil unrest on the city’s buildings, led to a walkout by dozens of staff members.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Condition of Black Life Is One of Mourning’
description: After nearly two weeks of national unrest, Claudia Rankine reflects on the reality of repetition in the systems of institutionalized racism.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: U.S. Marine Corps Issues Ban on Confederate Battle Flags
description: The directive, which was announced on Friday, details what is prohibited in Marine installations, office buildings and work spaces.
content: The U.S. Marine Corps on Friday issued detailed directives about removing and banning public displays of the Confederate battle flag at Marine installations — an order that extended to such items as mugs, posters and bumper stickers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: F.D.A. Says Some Masks Made in China Shouldn’t Be Reused
description: The agency is revising its rules, saying some N95 masks mainly used by health care workers and emergency responders cannot undergo decontamination for further use.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Sunday changed its policy on decontamination for some N95 masks mainly used by health professionals, saying certain masks made in China should not be reused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Shigeru Yokota, 87, Dies; Fought for Return of Abducted Daughter
description: He became the head of a group that fought tirelessly for the return to Japan of more than a dozen people kidnapped by the North Korean government.
content: Shigeru Yokota, whose tireless campaign for the return of his kidnapped daughter and other abductees from North Korea made him a well-known figure in Japan,  died on Friday outside Tokyo. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China and India Move to Defuse Tensions After Clashes in the Himalayas
description: The confrontations between troops along their shared border led to injuries and the most serious tensions between the two Asian powers in years.
content: China and India have stepped back from a tense confrontation along their shared border high in the Himalayas, pledging to resolve disputes over territory through diplomatic and military channels, India’s Foreign Ministry said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: For a Trailblazing Female Composer, a Prestigious Recording
description: Amy Beach’s Piano Quintet is on a new album from the Takacs Quartet and Garrick Ohlsson.
content: Progress remains all too slow, but the classical music industry is taking halting steps toward gender equality. Female conductors are taking their place on the podium more than ever before; women are among the most important composers writing today. There has even been a notable rise of interest in music by figures from the past: Clara Schumann, Louise Farrenc and Florence Price, to name just three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Marcolini, Emily Rhyne and Ora DeKornfeld
title: ‘It’s Unbelievable That We Have to Keep Doing This’: Protesters March to the White House
description: Thousands gathered in Washington, D.C., on Saturday to protest George Floyd’s death, racism and police brutality. From speeches to line dances, here’s what we saw and whom we met.
content: Thousands gathered in Washington, D.C., on Saturday to protest George Floyd’s death, racism and police brutality. From speeches to line dances, here’s what we saw and whom we met.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Shigeru Yokota, 87, Dies; Fought for Return of Abducted Daughter
description: He became the head of a group that fought tirelessly for the return to Japan of more than a dozen people kidnapped by the North Korean government.
content: Shigeru Yokota, whose tireless campaign for the return of his kidnapped daughter and other abductees from North Korea made him a well-known figure in Japan,  died on Friday outside Tokyo. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Emile Ducke
title: Giving Your Number to Strangers? It’s Not Flirting; It’s a Rule
description: As Berlin emerges from its lockdown, residents are getting used to social distancing in bars and swimming pools — and to handing out their phone number several times a day to help in contact tracing.
content: BERLIN — I’ve given my phone number to a lot of strangers over the past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Julia Jacobs
title: Floyd Case Forces Arts Groups to Enter the Fray
description: Cultural institutions are feeling compelled to stand up for racial justice, but artists and activists want action, not just statements of solidarity.
content: The apologies keep coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China and India Move to Defuse Tensions After Clashes in the Himalayas
description: The confrontations between troops along their shared border led to injuries and the most serious tensions between the two Asian powers in years.
content: China and India have stepped back from a tense confrontation along their shared border high in the Himalayas, pledging to resolve disputes over territory through diplomatic and military channels, India’s Foreign Ministry said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: James Bennet Resigns as New York Times Opinion Editor
description: A. G. Sulzberger noted “a significant breakdown in our editing processes” before the publication of an Op-Ed by a United States senator calling for a military response to civic unrest.
content: James Bennet resigned on Sunday from his job as the editorial page editor of The New York Times, days after the newspaper’s opinion section, which he oversaw, published a much-criticized Op-Ed by a United States senator calling for a military response to civic unrest in American cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Nationwide Protests, Unemployment, Rosé: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and David Zucchino
title: Protests Swell Across America as George Floyd Is Mourned Near His Birthplace
description: People lined up for hours before a viewing and a memorial service in a small North Carolina town, while demonstrations across the country grew larger and more organized.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Protesters in Philadelphia stood on the steps of an art museum and demanded cuts to the city’s police budget. A crowd gathered outside the Minnesota governor’s mansion stood silently to hear stories from victims of police abuse. At a huge rally in Washington, demonstrators filled the streets, and speakers cried out to ensure that a death like that of George Floyd under the knee of a Minneapolis police officer never happen again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek M. Norman
title: ‘You Have to Be Willing to Get a Bit Uncomfortable’: How a Reporter Covers a Protest
description: A lot of thought goes into how best to capture the scene and the individual stories behind it, but in the end, anything can happen.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Minneapolis Mayor Booed Out of Rally
description: Chanting “Shame” and “Go home, Jacob, go home,” demonstrators drove Mayor Jacob Frey out of a rally after he would not commit to abolishing the police.
content: Chanting “Shame” and “Go home, Jacob, go home,” demonstrators drove Mayor Jacob Frey out of a rally after he would not commit to abolishing the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: When Dickens Died, America Mourned. Our Archives Tell the Story.
description: The outpouring of grief after the novelist’s death, The Times wrote, was no surprise, since his books — “more or less associated with the events of our lives” — had touched people so profoundly.
content: When Charles Dickens died of an apparent stroke on June 9, 1870, the news was not cabled to the United States until later that night. Many New Yorkers did not learn about the British novelist’s death until the morning of June 11, when it was splashed across the front page of The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Ivanka Trump Blames ‘Cancel Culture’ for Pulled Speech. College Says It Took a Stand.
description: Wichita State University Tech pulled Ms. Trump’s commencement speech after students and faculty members condemned the Trump administration’s response to protests.
content: WASHINGTON — After a technical school in Kansas pulled a commencement speech recorded by Ivanka Trump, the president’s eldest daughter, she released the speech anyway and asserted that she was the victim of “cancel culture.” But those at the school who had led the charge against her said on Sunday that they had taken a stand against something broader: the divisiveness of the administration in which Ms. Trump serves as a senior adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
title: U.K. Lab to Sidestep Drug Industry to Sell Potential Virus Vaccine
description: Imperial College aims to develop a vaccine that is cheaper and easier to manufacture and is forming a partnership to sell it in low-income countries and Britain.
content: LONDON — A prominent British laboratory is forming a special partnership that would sidestep the drug industry to sell a potential vaccine against the coronavirus without profits or licensing fees in Britain and in low- and middle-income countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: China Vowed to Keep Wildlife Off the Menu, a Tough Promise to Keep
description: The government has moved slowly to permanently stop the sale and consumption of wild animals in the wake of the coronavirus epidemic, raising fears the practice may continue.
content: Bamboo rats lifted Mao Zuqin out of poverty. Now, because of the coronavirus pandemic, poverty threatens again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: ‘Pandemic Within a Pandemic’: Coronavirus and Police Brutality Roil Black Communities
description: The current civil unrest is deeply connected to the racial disparities exposed by the coronavirus crisis. “I’m just as likely to die from a cop as I am from Covid,” one organizer said.
content: WASHINGTON — When Mike Griffin, a black community organizer in Minneapolis, took to the streets in protest, he was grieving for two black men taken during the turmoil convulsing the country: George Floyd, who died after gasping for air under the knee of a white police officer, and his own godfather, who succumbed to Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Despite Big Promises, U.S. Has Delivered Limited Aid in Global Virus Response
description: The State Department and U.S.A.I.D. have spent a fraction of the humanitarian assistance that Congress approved in March to help curb the coronavirus.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has lauded itself as leading the world in confronting the coronavirus. But it has so far failed to spend more than 75 percent of the American humanitarian aid that Congress provided three months ago to help overseas victims of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Minneapolis Mayor Booed Out of Rally
description: Chanting “Shame” and “Go home, Jacob, go home,” demonstrators drove Mayor Jacob Frey out of a rally after he would not commit to abolishing the police.
content: Chanting “Shame” and “Go home, Jacob, go home,” demonstrators drove Mayor Jacob Frey out of a rally after he would not commit to abolishing the police.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Did The Source Cover the 1992 Los Angeles Uprisings?
description: Two former editors look back at the magazine’s on-the-ground reporting following the Rodney King verdict.
content: The Source, which was founded in the late 1980s and billed itself as “The Magazine of Hip-Hop Music, Culture & Politics,” was still in its infancy when the police officers who were filmed beating Rodney King after a 1991 traffic stop were not convicted at trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Better an Arms Treaty Than Not
description: A former State Department official cautions against abandoning the Open Skies Treaty. Also: Child care; restrictions on public gatherings in Hong Kong.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Tropical Storm Cristobal Makes Landfall in Louisiana
description: Meteorologists were watching for persistent bands of rain that can lead to flash flooding.
content: Tropical Storm Cristobal made landfall in southeast Louisiana late on Sunday afternoon, hours after pouring several inches of rain on the New Orleans area, the National Weather Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Farmers Get Billions in Virus Aid, and Democrats Are Wary
description: As the administration sends up to $16 billion in additional subsidies, critics are concerned that the funds could be used to ensure that the president maintains the backing of one of his key voting blocs.
content: WASHINGTON — Cotton farmers were paid 33 times as much in federal subsidies in 2019 as the income they actually lost to trade disruptions, one study showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: De Blasio Vows for First Time to Cut Funding for the N.Y.P.D.
description: The mayor made his pledge following 10 nights of mass protests against police violence and mounting demands for an overhaul of the police department.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Sunday pledged for the first time to cut the city’s police funding, following 10 nights of mass protests against police violence and mounting demands that he overhaul a department whose tactics have caused widespread consternation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In New York Protests, a Night Without Curfew or Conflict
description: Without a time limit to enforce, the police took a relatively passive approach and protesters, while loud, largely avoided confrontation.
content: The 11th day of protests in New York City set off in several locations with sunny skies and two significant accomplishments already won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: New York City Begins Reopening After 3 Months of Outbreak and Hardship
description: As many as 400,000 people may return to work on Monday in a city still recovering from the pandemic and roiled by protests.
content: Exactly 100 days since its first case of coronavirus was confirmed, New York City, which weathered extensive hardship as an epicenter of the worldwide outbreak, is set to take the first tentative steps toward reopening its doors on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden to Meet With George Floyd’s Family Ahead of Funeral
description: Mr. Biden will travel to Houston on Monday to offer his condolences to the family of Mr. Floyd, whose killing touched off nationwide protests over police brutality against black Americans.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will travel on Monday to Houston to meet with the family of George Floyd, a black man whose death at the hands of the police touched off a nationwide outcry over racism and police brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘I May Destroy You’ and ‘This Country’
description: Catch Michaela Coel’s new drama on HBO. And stream a mockumentary-style comedy about life in a small English village.
content: I MAY DESTROY YOU 10:30 p.m. on HBO. Michaela Coel, the British playwright, actress and star of the Netflix series “Chewing Gum,” is back with a new half-hour drama that explores big ideas about dating, exploitation and consent. Coel plays a popular writer named Arabella, who, during an all-night bender with friends, is drugged and assaulted. “The 12-part series alternates between big-picture stories about Arabella’s similarly sexually adventurous peers and some more subjective and disturbing sequences where she reckons with the lingering trauma of what happened to her,” Noel Murray wrote for The New York Times. He added that the series “is not always an easy show to watch, but it should be a conversation-starter.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Learned That Day That a Block Is Actually Pretty Long, East to West’
description: The high price of skimping on movers, a long walk home and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Car Drives Through Protesters in Brooklyn
description: A man was arrested near Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn after striking at least one person with his car.
content: A man was arrested near Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn after striking at least one person with his car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Eat well in the coming days with Aaron Hutcherson’s creamy white bean and fennel casserole, Tejal Rao’s toor dal, and Julia Moskin’s black bean soup.
content: Good morning. It is the birthday of the poet Gwendolyn Brooks, who died 20 years ago at the age of 83. You should celebrate it by reading “The Bean Eaters,” from 1963, a poem that ends in a stanza of stark beauty:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: A Daughter Is Beheaded, and Iran Asks if Women Have a Right to Safety
description: The so-called honor killing of a 14-year-old girl in Iran has shaken the country and forced an examination of its failure to protect women and children.
content: Before he beheaded his 14-year-old daughter with a farming sickle, Reza Ashrafi called a lawyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Kurt Thomas, Trailblazing Champion Gymnast, Dies at 64
description: The first American to win a world championship in men’s gymnastics, he captured many medals but missed out on his best chance to take Olympic gold.
content: Kurt Thomas, who became the first American to win a world championship event in men’s gymnastics when he captured gold in the floor exercise at Strasbourg, France, in 1978, died on Friday. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
content: EL CENTRO, Calif. — For 32 years, Judy Cruz has cared for patients who showed up in the emergency room in the arid, agrarian valley that straddles Mexico along the California border.
source.name: The New York Times

Coel plays a popular writer named Arabella, who, during an all-night bender with friends, is drugged and assaulted. “The 12-part series alternates between big-picture stories about Arabella’s similarly sexually adventurous peers and some more subjective and disturbing sequences where she reckons with the lingering trauma of what happened to her,” Noel Murray wrote for The New York Times. author: By David Gelles
title: When the Office Is Like a Biohazard Lab
description: “If people have to stay six feet apart and have to wear masks, why are we bringing them back?”
content: Here’s what it will be like when Cisco employees return to the office:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: You Live Outside New York. Are You Ready to Return to Broadway?
description: Some readers are primed to take their seats, masks on, but more are hesitant: “My love of theater is not so important to me that I risk dying for it.”
content: New Yorkers are reluctant to return to the theater this fall, according to a survey commissioned by The New York Times. What about out-of-towners, who make up more than two-thirds of the Broadway audience? What would it take for them to be comfortable?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Barr Says There Is No Systemic Racism in Policing
description: The attorney general’s remarks, which mirrored those of other administration officials, came as the president was scheduled to meet with law enforcement officials at the White House.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr said on Sunday that he did not believe racism was a systemic problem in policing, echoing other top administration officials’ defense of an important part of President Trump’s base as protests against police killings of unarmed black people continued across the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Alicia Parlapiano, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Karthik Patanjali, Bedel Saget, Anjali Singhvi, Jin Wu and Karen Yourish
title: Bird’s Eye View of Protests Across the U.S. and Around the World
description: Images from Saturday, June 6, show the scale of the protests against police brutality and racism, following the death of George Floyd.
content: Images from Saturday, June 6, show the scale of the protests against police brutality and racism, following the death of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is It Safe for Summer Camps to Open?
description: Camp officials and parents discuss the tough decisions camp are facing.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Hails Its Virus Triumphs, and Glosses Over Its Mistakes
description: Trying to win a propaganda tug of war, Beijing staunchly defended its actions, saying it didn’t hide the emergence of the outbreak.
content: BEIJING — Under continued fire for its early mishandling of the coronavirus, the Chinese government vigorously defended its actions in a new, detailed account on Sunday that portrays the country’s approach to combating the outbreak as a model for the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
content: Nine members — a veto-proof majority — of the Minneapolis City Council pledged on Sunday to dismantle the city’s Police Department, promising to create a new system of public safety in a city where law enforcement has long been accused of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: For Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis, a Stinging Rebuke
description: A sea of protesters yelled, “Go home, Jacob, go home!” and “Shame! Shame!” when he would not, on the spot, commit to abolishing the Police Department.
content: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis retreated on Saturday through a sea of protesters yelling, “Go home, Jacob, go home!” and “Shame! Shame!” after he refused to commit to defunding the Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: For Years, He Was Spank Rock. He’s Always Been Naeem.
description: The rapper who burst out in 2006 with the rollicking “YoYoYoYoYo” is returning with “Startisha,” his first new album in nine years, and a newfound comfort with speaking his truth.
content: Close your eyes, open your ears and picture a rapper called Spank Rock. What type of music do you think he makes?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Larry Fitzgerald Jr.: This Is Not the Minneapolis of My Youth
description: The Arizona Cardinals star wide receiver writes of present-day unrest and recalls a more peaceful time in his hometown. “We are not listening to one another.”
content: The city of Minneapolis taught me about love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: U.S. protests, China, New York City: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Anti-racism protesters flooded the streets in cities and towns across the United States over the weekend, calling for reforms to the nation’s police forces and to the justice system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Umansky
title: Find Poetry in the Pages of a Newspaper
description: The hardest part about writing poetry is choosing the right words. Use a paper or magazine as raw material to get over the first hurdle.
content: These days, people are turning to art or poetry while stuck at home, because they want to feel something other than being at home. One way to feel something different and exciting is to craft a found poem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: How Great Minds Think
description: Kyle Dolan opens our solving week.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Please help me welcome back the constructor Kyle Dolan, and congratulations to him for hitting for the cycle, which means that he now has a puzzle published in The New York Times for each day of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Mayor de Blasio, Don’t Make New York’s Budget Crisis Worse
description: Borrowing $7 billion without smart spending cuts will leave the city in a yearslong fiscal bind.
content: As the coronavirus crisis wreaks havoc on the lives and livelihoods of millions of Americans, state and local governments are struggling to meet the needs of their people. In New York City, the epicenter of the pandemic, the devastation is particularly acute and promises to grind on indefinitely. Mayor Bill de Blasio confronts unfamiliar and difficult budget decisions. He has not met the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Allies, Don’t Fail Us Again
description: Many white people have been moved by the current movement, but how will they respond when true equality threatens their privilege?
content: In 1964, during what was called Freedom Summer, over 700 mostly white young liberals descended on Mississippi to help register black voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: J.K. Rowling Under Fire by L.G.B.T.Q. Groups Over Tweets
description: The creator of the “Harry Potter” series faced a backlash after she took aim at an article that referred to “people who menstruate.”
content: J.K. Rowling, the creator of the popular “Harry Potter” series, came under fire from L.G.B.T.Q. groups after she took aim at an article that referred to “people who menstruate.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mayor de Blasio, Don’t Make New York’s Budget Crisis Worse

content: As the coronavirus crisis wreaks havoc on the lives and livelihoods of millions of Americans, state and local governments are struggling to meet the needs of their people. In New York City, the epicenter of the pandemic, the devastation is particularly acute and promises to grind on indefinitely. Mayor Bill de Blasio confronts unfamiliar and difficult budget decisions. He has not met the moment.

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Allies, Don’t Fail Us Again
description: Many white people have been moved by the current movement, but how will they respond when true equality threatens their privilege?
content: In 1964, during what was called Freedom Summer, over 700 mostly white young liberals descended on Mississippi to help register black voters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Reopening States Are Blindsided by Protests
description: The F.D.A. is warning against reusing some masks made in China. Democrats fear farm aid is meant to bolster Trump’s campaign.
content: Before the eruption of outrage over the killing of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis, debates about reopening centered on whether states had adequate systems in place to detect and treat cases of the coronavirus, which has killed more than 110,000 people in the United States since the beginning of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Inside the Revolts Erupting in America’s Big Newsrooms
description: Staff members’ demands helped end the tenure of James Bennet as Opinion editor of The New York Times. And they are generating tension at The Washington Post. Part of the story starts in Ferguson, Mo.
content: Wesley Lowery woke up in Ferguson, Mo., on Aug. 14, 2014, his cheek sore from where a police officer had smashed it into a vending machine. He was also wondering how to get his shoelaces back into his boat shoes, after the police took them when tossing him in a holding cell the night before. Around 8:30 that morning, he dialed into CNN’s morning show, where a host passed on some advice from Joe Scarborough at MSNBC: “Next time a police officer tells you that you’ve got to move along because you’ve got riots outside, well, you probably should move along.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Helene Cooper
title: Trump Orders Troops to Leave D.C. as Former Military Leaders Sound Warning
description: The president said National Guard soldiers would withdraw “now that everything is under perfect control,” even as three former Joint Chiefs chairmen condemned his use of military force.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Sunday that he had ordered National Guard troops to begin withdrawing from the nation’s capital, after a week of relentless criticism over his threat to militarize the government’s response to nationwide protests, including rebukes from inside the military establishment itself.
source.name: The New York Times
